section.name: Compound type
section.p: Diagram of a complex layout build up from elemental layouts. Such a complex layout can be defined for all documents of a particular type by using compound types.

Document types can be defined by nesting compound types. This allows reuse of types and the easy definition of complex layouts for documents. The documents are presented with that layout in the document editor.

A compound type is a simplified variant of a document type. Each document type and each compound type may consist of other compound types and each compound type is itself a component of its parent compound type or a document type.

Each document type and each compound type defines an elemental layout for its components. Java developers can define several custom elemental layouts from which information architects can choose in the CMS. The standard CMS supplies several elemental layouts to choose from, e.g.: two-column, vertical list and horizontal list. By nesting these compounds, complex layouts can be created. The diagram above shows an example of a complex layout build up from the elemental layouts.

Of course, document types and compound types may also contain simple fields like strings. Compound types are a way to define building blocks of fields that can be reused in several document types or other compound types.
